node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.title: Your Biggest Delta Variant Questions Answered

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.text:
“It was really impossible not to feel the immediacy, the urgency of climate change on this leg of the trip.”

Frank Barry stops in #Iowa and #Colorado, continuing his journey across the U.S. along the Lincoln Highway.

Video by @quicktake, footage by @looking4lincoln.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 13, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and text that says 'Here's why President Xi Jinping wants cheaper weddings for China BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
💍 The Chinese government says many wedding customs — including "bride prices" and groom hazing — are now officially frowned upon. Will anyone listen? 

In Chongqing, one of China’s biggest cities, engaged couples will soon be eligible for a government-sponsored group wedding. The goal of the reform is to eliminate costs and customs that are contributing to China’s declining marriage and birth rates, writes Adam Minter. 

Officials hope the reforms will help prevent a looming population decline. It’s a risky bet. Rather than produce a baby boom, it’s more likely to produce resentment. 

Click the link in our bio to read the full column.

node.text:
🚨Calling all math fanatics: Today is the last "true" Fibonacci Day of the century.

August 13, 2021 is perfectly in line with Leonardo Fibonacci De Pisa's famous mathematical concept: the Fibonacci sequence.

The series of numbers starts with 1 and 1, and each number after is found by adding the two previous numbers. So 1 + 1 = 2, 1 + 2 = 3, 2 +3 = 5 and so on.

That's why today is so special, explains Scott Duke Kominers: 8-13-21 will be the *last* date that corresponds with the sequence until a century from now.

Crazy, right?

For more puzzling math facts and riddles, check out the latest Kominers’s Conundrums, link in bio.

#fibonacci #fibonaccispiral #fibonaccisequence #math #history

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'AnAMC GameStop collab makes total sense today universe BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Look, if you run a meme-stock company, you have to announce earnings four times a year, and then you will probably want to do an earnings call. If, on that earnings call, you take questions from your enthusiastic individual shareholders, (1) the questions will be insane, (2) your answers will be insane, (3) the shareholders will love it and (4) the stock will go up.

AMC did this, and got asked this: "Will AMC consider partnering with GameStop to offer more theater experiences via local and national gaming competitions?"

And its CEO Adam M. Aron replied with this: "I don't even think I can count the number of times people have asked me if we could partner with GameStop. We're certainly willing to do so."

Yes, right! Put the GameStop in the AMC! Drive there in a Tesla that you rented at a Hertz! Pay for your tickets with Dogecoin! Cram the whole thing into a rocket ship and send it to Mars! This is how finance works now; the goal is to say as many meme-trade buzzwords as possible because that is what makes stocks go up. That’s why you do a call like this, writes Matt Levine.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about AMC's wild ride.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What really happened to inequality in the pandemic? BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Many are assuming that the pandemic has exacerbated an already-strong trend toward increasing economic inequality in the U.S. And for good reason: the richest top 1% have seen the value of their stocks and assets soar.

But Justin Fox explains that it's not that simple: "The numbers available so far, while preliminary and in some cases a bit contradictory, aren’t really telling a story of exploding inequality."

The bottom 50% actually enjoyed a bigger percentage wealth gain than the top 1% —30.3% versus 20.7% since the end of 2019 — although because it had so little wealth to start with, that amounted to just $609 billion in new wealth versus $7.1 trillion for the 1%. Still, the total wealth of the bottom 50% in the first quarter of this year amounted to 6.3% of that of the top 1%, up from 5.8% at the end of 2019 and the highest such percentage since 2007. In that sense, at least, inequality between the top and bottom decreased.

That's not the only good news on inequality. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#inequality #wealth #pandemic #poverty

Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says '...poverty also dropped by some measures as the bottom half climbed Share of of U.S. household wealth for bottom 50% 4% 2 1989 2000 Sou:FedeaR 2010 2020 BloombergOpinion'.

Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 12, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, money and text that says 'While the resto the world is trading Bitcoin and Ethereum, the Chinese will be left on the sidelines BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
China is trapped in its own digital currency universe.

Authorities banned banks and finance firms from providing Bitcoin and other cryptocurrency services and shut down most mining operations, tipping off a mass exodus of equipment from the country.

Beijing’s policy toward virtual currencies is making it an outlier and cutting the economy off from a major new trend in international finance. Without a shift in approach, China could well be the one that gets left behind, writes Michael Schuman.

Beijing’s distrust of cryptos is indicative of the government’s greater and growing wariness of private enterprise more broadly. What's going on is a fundamental revision of the relationship between the state and private sector, with long-term consequences for China’s position in the global economy.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'There's very little chance we can keep warming under 1.5℃ now Total co. emissions, 1850-2019 Remaining budget 2,390 gigatonnes(Gt) of CO2 300 Human-induced warming =1.07℃ As little 900Gt or as much as 2,300Gt may cause temperatures to reach 2C above the pre-industrial level. 900 1.5°℃ 500 (50% chance) 550 1,450 1.07℃ 1.7℃ 850 900 1.07°℃ 2,300 2019 level 2.0℃ 1,350 Note: Thehigher and lower numbers each scenario 17% and 83% chances staying under each temperature limit. The world emitted Gt CO2ir 2020 Source AR6 Working Group report BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The new report from the UN’ #IPCC is fairly dire — and exactly what you’d expect, given that humanity has so far declined to make deep cuts in worldwide greenhouse emissions. Scientists now estimate that there’s very little chance of holding warming below 1.5 degrees Celsius relative to pre-industrial levels. Instead, the battle is now to keep warming under 2°C.

Noah Smith is feeling hopeful though: "Technology has made climate change a solvable problem by expanding the universe of the possible.  Before advancements made renewable energy a cost-effective solution, nation's faced a hellish tradeoff between climate disaster or material impoverishment. Now, thanks to the efforts of scientists, engineers and entrepreneurs, that tradeoff no longer exists." Thanks to this technology, the extreme scenarios in which Earth turns into a version of Dante’s Hell have now been effectively ruled out.

But there’s a powerful force acting to stop governments from making full use of these technologies — especially in the U.S. and China, the world’s top two carbon emitters. That force is the political power of the fossil fuel industry, in particular, oil and natural gas companies in America and coal companies in China. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#climatechange #climatebreakdown #renewableenergy #climate #science #tech

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in Sakha Republic. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Smoke from Siberia's wildfires has reached the North Pole for the first time inrecordedhistory ecorded BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The weather disasters spanning the globe this summer — infernal fires in Siberia and Greece, deadly floods from Germany to China, heat waves from Canada to California — are really just nature’s shots across our bow.

"That becomes clear if you absorb this week’s report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the body of the United Nations that assesses the state of science on global warming. No matter what policies we adopt — and obviously we should aim for good ones — the weather will keep getting more catastrophic more often," writes Andreas Kluth.

One particular concern is the polar jet stream, a group of winds that whips at enormous speeds around the Arctic from west to east (owing to the earth’s rotation) at a height of six-to-10 miles up in the atmosphere.

The complex swirls of the jet streams tend to blow away pressure systems that could otherwise kill us on the ground with storms and floods and heat. If these streams blow less hard, those meteorological danger domes just hover in place without moving, until they discharge their payloads on us.

Whether and when such a “tipping point” will be reached remains controversial among scientists. But if this is our destiny, the world will never be the same again. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#wildfire #siberia #northpole #jetstream #climate #ipcc #russia #history

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 11, 2021. May be an image of body of water and text that says 'Should you throw out all your sunscreen now or what? BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
☀️It’s the middle of the U.S. summer vacation season, and reports on the presence of a potential carcinogen in sunscreen have some people thinking twice about their outdoor protection regimen.

The sunscreen safety debate is neither new nor easy to solve, writes Max Nisen.

Researchers petitioned the FDA last week to recall sunscreens containing the commonly-used chemical octocrylene after finding it was associated with the presence of a possible carcinogen and hormone disruptor called benzophenone. What’s unclear is if the concentrations found in the products are high enough or enough is absorbed for them to be an issue.

Regardless, you shouldn't avoid sunscreen this summer. The dangers of chemical sunscreens are still uncertain, especially relative to the risk of developing skin cancer.

👀Be on the lookout for recalls and updated FDA guidance, and tap the link in our bio for more details.

#fda #sunscreen #recall #sun #science #sunburn

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Teens now have easier access to sportsgambling than ever before 1OA 3NT SIADIE BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
💰DraftKings, a leading operator of fantasy sports leagues and digital betting platforms, said Monday that it plans to buy Golden Nugget Online Gaming for $1.56 billion. Penn National Gaming said last week it that it will buy Sports Media and Gaming, an online sports betting company, for $1.74 billion.

"Both deals exemplify all the lines between sports and gambling that have become blurred in recent years," writes Tim O'Brien.

Sports gambling is fun, of course, and when pursued in moderation, harmless. But the U.S. has never before encountered the perpetual motion machine that sports betting and the sports business have become in the digital era, O'Brien explains.

Children and teens who were once shielded from gambling, and who aren’t typically fans of moderation, now have easier access to sports betting and marketing than ever before. And the more money that is circulating, the greater is the temptation to try stealing it.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'SoftBank doesn' have the cashfo Masa Son's "buy, buy, buy" strategy Current Ratio 1.4 1.2 1.0 0.8 2011 2014 2016 Note: ratio Crens current assets/current liabilities Source: Bloomberg, SoftBank Group 2018 0.6 2020 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
SoftBank’s prolific spending on startups underpins founder Masayoshi Son’s entire strategy, driving both earnings and share price. But its balance sheet is now in a hole that suggests the only way out is to start selling, writes Tim Culpan

Net income at the Japanese company dropped 39% for the June quarter, while profit at its eponymous investment unit plunged almost 90% amid a decline in the share prices of key holdings like ride-hailing provider Uber and Coupang.

Another key metric of its financial position has plunged to the lowest level in almost three years — SoftBank’s current ratio, which measures current assets divided by current liabilities.

Bankers and bondholders expect 8.6 trillion yen ($78 billion) in the next 12 months to be repaid on time, which means further investments will need to take a backseat to selling assets and raising cash.

Will SoftBank prove to shareholders that its spending spree was worth the bet? Tap the link in our bio to find out.

node.text:
It's official: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has announced his resignation after harassment allegations.

He is the latest reminder that the U.S. could really use a more foolproof system for removing leaders.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in Cambridge, Massachusetts. May be an image of text that says 'Moderna is the hottest stock in pharma, thanks to its vaccine Moderna current market cap AstraZeneca Bristol-Myers Squibb Amgen Merck AbbVie $300B 200 100 2020 Source: Souce:Bloomberg 2021 BloombergOpinic'.

node.text:
📈 Moderna's value has soared past other drugmakers on the strength of a single product: its Covid-19 vaccine.

"As of now, the Covid jab is the company's only approved product, and its finite future sales depend on the very uncertain trajectory of the pandemic and booster shots," writes Max Nisen.

Single-product companies are usually targets rather than buyers when it comes to biotech. But Moderna is in the rare position of having the firepower to go on the hunt itself.

Moderna has plenty of deal capacity, with $12.2 billion in cash on hand and more coming in. Tap the link in our bio to read all about its acquisition strategy.
